The orders kept piling up, and so did the mistakes. A forgotten garnish here, an overcooked steak there. Each slip-up chipped away at her resolve until she felt raw, exposed. Like she was standing in front of a sold-out crowd, naked but for a pair of chef's whites.

She caught Jake watching her again. This time, he didn't look away when she glared. Instead, he said softly, "Hey, it's okay. You don't have to do everything yourself."

But that was the problem, wasn't it? She did have to. Because if she stopped, if she let herself rest for just a moment, then all those dark thoughts would rush in like a tidal wave. Thoughts of failure, of loss, of being utterly, hopelessly alone.

So she kept going, kept pushing through the pain and the noise and the endless parade of orders. Because that was her life now - a relentless march towards... what? She didn't know anymore. But at least in the kitchen, amidst the chaos, she could pretend she had some control.

Her phone buzzed again. And again. And again. Each vibration another tiny reminder that she wasn't alone. Yet, she felt more isolated than ever. Trapped in her own personal hell, one chopped onion at a time.

When the rush finally ended, and the last plate was cleared, she collapsed against the counter, breathless and shaking. Jake handed her a towel to wipe her face, but she couldn't meet his eyes. She didn't want him to see the fear there, the sheer terror of knowing that tomorrow would be just like today.

Because what if it wasn't? What if one day she couldn't get up again? What if this endless, hopeless cycle finally swallowed her whole?

But for now, there was work to do. Always more work. So she took a deep breath, squared her shoulders, and got back to chopping. One onion at a time.
